Solution looking for a problem? Tech-bro imperialism? Reinventing a wheel as a rotating cloud-enabled subscription hub? Sure, all of that. Here's Citi.

BE11:27am

Facebook’s Libra initiative could be one of the
most well organized efforts by a global consumer tech company yet. The currency
could have a variety of applications, from P2P money transfer to merchant shopping (including on Instagram Shopping and Facebook Marketplace). As Zuckerberg said at this year’s F8, “sending money should be as easy as sending someone a photo.” Libra could introduce a meaningful new product and profit stream for FB over the coming years. That said, the regulatory framework for cryptocurrencies remains uncertain, and Libra will also be an important test for how well Facebook has been able to (or will be able to) overcome the recent questions about its trustworthiness.

den Good morn (rather late)

#REF! @red I'm not questioning people will sign away their rights easily. What I'm questioning is why people will pay for stuff with this when the current system works so well? Why swithc
Shinshin I think the slow coming together of all the Alipay bits - paytm, Worldfirst, etc - is the more interesting story. Anyone keen to see the future of payment transmission is better off booking a short tour of second-tier Chinese cities than reading the Fluffbook nonsense.
BE11:28am

Other things to consider include the following: 1) Facebook has enlisted some of its strongest execs in the Libra effort (e.g., David Marcus, Kevin Weil, Hui Ding, etc.); 2) reports suggest that Facebook has successfully lined up formal support from some of the most prominent firms in tech, retail, and payments e.g., Booking, Spotify, Uber, Lyft, Visa, MasterCard, PayPal, eBay, Stripe, Coinbase, Vodafone, etc.), including a commitment of at least $10mn from each member to gain access to the Libra node (reports suggest that Facebook aims to have 100 companies contributing a combined $1bn to the project); 3) Facebook’s Libra currency is reportedly launching in 1Q20 and will be tested in a dozen countries prior to then; 4) some have voiced concern about potential national sovereignty pushback and regulatory scrutiny within some countries; 5) to decentralize Libra from Facebook, the Libra currency and blockchain will reportedly be managed by a Geneva-based Libra Association and will be backed by a Libra Reserve (a reserve of hard assets that will provide stability and global acceptance) 6) Libra will be a “stablecoin,” and its value will be tied to a basket of fiat currencies (managed by the Libra Reserve) to minimize volatility, although some have voiced concern about user confusion/adoption if not using a crypto backed by a single currency; and 7) we expect that initial implementation of Libra within Facebook to potentially center around its messaging apps (including WhatsApp) and its users in developing countries.

BE11:32am

There are a number of other issues to consider. There is potential national sovereignty scrutiny and/or regulatory issues in various countries. By enabling users to transact directly on its platform, Facebook is hoping to improve conversion rates and keep users engaged on its services. Some expect it will enable Facebook will gain a first-hand look into users’ purchasing decisions, track conversions and capture rich data-pools of user information. However, what about privacy regulations, ‘do not track’ initiatives and regulations such as GDPR? And everyone seems to have forgotten that the FTC has begun an antitrust investigation into Facebook, and federal prosecutors are conducting a criminal investigation into data deals Facebook struck. Even if Facebook could become a hub for transactions the assumption appears to be that it would be in countries with high inflation or unstable banking systems (partly because there are already so many advanced payment infrastructure services and immediate/simple payment options in developed markets - Revolut our personal favourite).

Jamie Powell (FT Alphaville) Campling to the rescue!
BE11:32am

The point of Libra is likely a copy-cat of the highly successful WeChat-like payments and business transaction functionality as Facebook’s ultimate goal for its messaging platforms. But WeChat and payments and built from the ground up to grow with the platform rather than added to the platform after it had been created. WeChat didn’t face 100 other alternative fintech options. And many companies in developed markets have well established direct customer relationships. And the opportunity in developing economies is less clear. After all, the ARPU on the Facebook platform today is miniscule in the Rest of the World, at just $1.89 comparted to $30.12 in the US & Canada. Even in Europe ARPU is less than 1/3rd the level of North America. There isn’t a given that Libra can suddenly propel global ARPU significantly higher in coming years.

UBS incoming:

BE11:39am

We estimate EBITDA cons will decrease by c10% in 2019E.
In a press release, Siltronic updated its full year guidance with sales expected to be
down 10% to 15% in 2019E y-o-y (vs -5% to -10% previously and UBSe -14% y-o-y)
and EBITDA margin between 30% and 35% (vs 33% and 37% previously and UBSe
32%). This implies c10% downgrade to EBITDA consensus 2019. Siltronic also states
that ASP in euro in 2019 will be slightly higher than 2018 (consistent with previous
comments). It also expects net cash flow to remain clearly positive but will decline by
€180m (vs €150m previously). No change of capex has been announced.
We believe the downgrade was mostly expected
To justify the revision, Siltronic points out "continuing slowdown" driven by
geopolitical uncertainties which reduced "significantly" orders for H2 2019. Although
Q2 will be significantly lower than Q1 (like previously announced), Q3 will decrease
further. While we believe the revision was expected by the market (stock down more
than 30% since May), we believe it will be key for Siltronic to reassure on pricing
outlook for 2020 depending on the current long term contracts trend.

BE11:39am

UBS upgraded to neutral late last week, hence the "we think it's already anticipated" stuff.

11:41 am
BE11:41am

Siltronic has not disclosed 2Q FY19 guidance, but assuming 1H sales are flat YoY (ASP, volumes both flat), and based on its forecast for a 10–15% drop in full-year sales and flat prices, we estimate 2H sales will decline 19–29% YoY (prior estimate: 10–19%) and sales volumes will contract 19–29% (10–19%). We forecast an especially steep YoY decline in shipments of 200mm and smaller-diameter wafers amid weak demand from the auto sector, but we also anticipate a slump in shipments of 300mm wafers due to soft demand from Siltronic’s customers in North America, which have been affected by the ban on exports to Huawei. We currently forecast market shipments of 5.88mn 300mm wafers per month in 3Q 2019 (−7% YoY) and 5.88mn in 4Q (−7%), picking up from 5.64mn in 2Q. However, based on Siltronic’s 3Q sales outlook, which factors in the impact of the Huawei export ban, we now think 300mm demand in 2H could fall short of those forecasts, with some wafer companies pushing back wafer shipments for long-term contract customers into 2020.

PBT/EPS of £223m/35p was just below our estimates (£225m/36p) and c2% above consensus £220m/35p. At Sunbelt US 4Q rental revenue growth was 22% driven by +21% fleet on rent and +1% from yield. 4Q EBITDA margins were 47% (FY18: 48%) due to new stores while drop through in North America (US + Canada) improved to 46% in 4Q19 (4Q: 18: 27%) and 47% in FY19 (FY18: 46%). In the UK revenue growth remains low with margins modestly back, as the market remains challenged the group will not perform replacement capex in weak categories while re-stocking better areas allowing for a positive mix shift and stronger cash generation (greater than £100m in FY20 from c£60m in FY19).

red @Dec69 - Skepticthey will get bullish on brexit again after tory leadership. mkts eternal optimism never seems to go away. but some downside first.
chopper bear lay boris at 1.17 ? lol
BE11:49am

The outlook for FY20 revenue growth is 11-15% of which organic 9-12% (FY19: 15%, FY19 plan: 8-11%) and bolt-ons 2-3% (FY19: 5%, FY19 plan: 3-4%). We make modest changes to underlying assumptions but factoring in $ strength drives a 4% EPS upgrade in FY20/21. The outlook for capex in FY20 is similar to FY19, in the US capex at the mid-point is exactly in line, albeit with higher replacement vs growth capex while in Canada and A Plant capex is lower. Three bolt ons post year end have been completed for $22m of consideration although consistent with commentary at 3Q there are less deals in the hopper than a year ago. IFRS16 is expected to drive increase debt by £900m and net debt to EBITDA by 0.3-0.4x. Guidance is for an EBITDA increase of £100m, an EBITA increase of £15m and a PBT decrease of £30m (due to front end loaded nature of interest).

BE11:50am

While Sunbelt has progressed 14 markets to clusters, 76 of the top 100 markets are not clustered suggesting significant runway for growth which we anticipate will continue to be filled with greenfields and bolt ons. In this note we run through key leading indicators, which, while showing a moderating in growth rates from summer 2018 highs, suggest the cycle remains in good shape. With construction put in place below 2001 and 2006 peaks and Dodge forecasting the next trough (2021) in line with 2018, Ashtead should continue to demonstrate growth through a modest downturn.

BE11:51am

The outlook statement indicatespositive momentum has continued into FY20F, referencing “supportive end markets” and with May US rental revenue +19% AHT is off to a good start inmeeting its FY20target of low-teens revenue growth (we expect growth to slow through the year). Capex outlook for FY20F is unchanged from March guidance (c£1.6bn, at a similar level to FY19A), as are our underlying growth assumptions.We nudge up our forecasts for FX, and our FY21F EPS also benefits from our assumption that AHT continues its share buyback beyond FY20F at c£500m pa–overall FY20F EPS +1% and FY21F +4%. Our TP increases to 2230p (previously2200p), reflecting our EBITDA increase. Our target CY20E EV/EBITDA multiple is unchanged at 5.5x.AHT trades on a CY2020F EV/EBITDA of 5.0x and PE of 8.9x, compared to closest peer United Rentals, trading on 4.3xand 5.6xrespectively. The direction of AHT’s share price in the last 12months has largely been dictated by sentiment towards US construction markets, often with seemingly little regard for the structural growth being delivered. While we acknowledge the importance of non-resi construction for AHT, and also accept that a downturn is likely at some point in the next few years,we note the following:(i) our base case is not for a re-run of 2008-10in non-resi construction markets given the peak is less elevated this time round; (ii) AHT’s balance sheet is in significantly better shape than the last downturn; and (iii) AHT’s business mix has changed since the last downturn.

11:52 am
BE11:52am

The Q4 numbers speak to another quarter where the value of management’s strategy is being seen as the group far exceeds market growth at high margins and returns and management provided significant detail in the presentation on why this model can continue to deliver higher earnings and, importantly, a sustainably higher cash profile. On the nearterm, management is guiding to 11-15% revenue growth at Sunbelt in FY20 on flat capex with a minimum of £500m of share buy-backs, a framework that supports the 15-20% target annual EPS growth whilst remaining within the target leverage range. On the market backdrop, management confirmed a still very strong level of activity for Sunbelt underlined by May seeing revenue growth at 19% in the US (despite some adverse weather). We summarise here some of our key takeaways from the analyst presentation with our overall view being a positive one that supports both the outperformance of the shares today and more upside to come.

12:05 pm
BE12:05pm

We are Sellers of Future because:
Its recent addition to the FTSE 250 for the first time, along with exceptional reported organic growth has led to unrealistic market-implied expectations.
The worsening of website ranking data suggests that aggressive monetisation of Future's content, principally TechRadar and Tom's Hardware, is harming these brands' reputation.
Newly-acquired Purch should be dilutive to growth come 2020 with TopTenReviews a case study for the impact of monetisation.
We forecast Future's organic growth to slow sharply and believe historical reporting to have been overstated.
The quality of earnings is poor due to ongoing recurring charges while management representation of FCF is at odds with reality. In addition we highlight an uptick in ageing of receivables.
A warped management remuneration scheme has led to aggressive acquisitions to hit EBITDA targets and continues to encourage actions at odds with long term value creation.
